{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3295960,"name":"","username":"Computergeneratednam","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c4cdca/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-27T20:22:26.102Z","cooked":"

I’m currently calibrating 3 limelights, one limelight 3, and 2 limelight 2+'s. For the limelight 3 I got a pretty decent calibration reprojection error of 1.54. When I went to calibrate the 2+'s, I keep getting horrible results of 60+ although the way I took the pictures didn’t change. Any tips on how to get better results? I already read the documentation and took all the tips/tricks.

Also, if possible- can I use my 1.54 error projection result from the lime 3 to the other 2? If so this would make my life so much easier

We are also trying to calibrate a limelight 3 but haven’t been able to get a reproduction error below 50 with the standard calibration tool. How did you manage to calibrate the limelight accurately?

Switching to photonvision on our limelights solved the issue for us:

FRC 4481 Team Rembrandts | 2024 Build Thread | Open Alliance Open Alliance
Vision Improvements Earlier this week , we talked about auto aiming our Shamper using robot localization. For this, we use a WPILib SwerveDrivePoseEstimator along with corrective measurements from two Limelights. This works great… as long as your camera tracking works as intended. Unfortunately, we were facing some critical inaccuracies in the vision measurements, resulting in us spending the weekend on debugging the issues. Issues Upon further inspection, the inaccuracies in our system can be…

I’m not 100% sure, but the matrix of how the camera perceives the field around it is a pretty good indicator on where the error is coming from. What I did, is when the matrix had problems and unsure readings in a certain area I would take more pictures in that angle/specific area that it had bad readings in. It wasn’t a 100% guarantee that the calibration would improve from that, but it was definitely better than a shot in the dark.
